metadata.h1: Classifying Products as Banned Or Approved using Text Mining Part-I

all_paragraphs: Let me start with some facts that I have established over my limited encounters with machine learning based problems — ‘You can’t find the best fit as there is none, just keep trying — that’s the key’ and ‘data is the best investment option you have — spend a lot of time on it’.

Coming to the problem at hand — identify ‘banned’ content on Indiamart, an online platform which attracts millions of users every day. By ‘banned’ I mean the content which is not allowed as per the current legal framework in the country and what’s more -it’s dynamic. eg: A jacket made of cow leather is a ‘banned’ product while a leather upholstery executive revolving chair is not.
Before moving forward, let us get hold of what a product is in the context of Indiamart

Note: I will be using the product in the context of content in the article. A product here is nothing but a description of what content is available against a particular item. A product has a title, a description, an image of the item you are selling, it’s price etc.
We had to classify our products(new as well as existing)as Approved or Banned based on the information available against it.
For instance ,any product which mentions of narcotic salts needs to be marked as ‘banned’ and removed from the mainstream content.

In our current approach, we mark a product as banned or approved based on keyword match, i.e We have a list of banned keywords and if that keyword exists in the product’s name, we mark it as banned else mark it as approved.

What this lead to was that certain relevant products were being classified as banned though they should have been approved eg. ‘Cat’ is present in our list of banned keywords, so products like ‘wooden cat gift pieces’, ‘CAT Bulldozer’ etc got banned which led to the loss of good content.

A supervised text-based classifier which was trained using previously labeled examples played the trick for us. The goal of this classifier was to categorize a product in one of the two labels ‘Banned’ or ‘Approved’ .eg of the labels used for training
_label_Approved dell wireless mouse black color

We fed the machine with an existing set of products labeled as ‘Banned’ or ‘Approved’ for it to build a relationship so that it can predict whether a product should be accepted or rejected. Then a different set of products was again fed to the machine and it was asked whether this product should be accepted or rejected.
We were able to better capture the intent and context of the product this time- a CAT bulldozer or a CAT Excavator was not ‘banned’ while ‘cat fur jacket’ was banned.
The description and specifications available against products (which was not being considered in the existing keyword service ) were also used to train and test the model.
We used fastText to train our model. fastText is an open source library from Facebook for efficient learning of word representations and sentence classification.
In case you are new to fastText and face issues running it, please refer to this video tutorial.
Training Data: A file having labeled data rows. All products essentially had one of the two labels either ‘Banned’ or ‘Approved’ and the corpus was all the content available against the product.

Note: The hyper-parameters used here have been selected after performing hyper-parameter tuning which allows you to get parameters which will help you get an enhanced accuracy for your use case. These may vary depending upon the data-set under consideration

K Fold Cross Validation was used to validate the model.
An interesting example: Samsung mobile phones which are not banned while their fake counterparts are banned. Can the model detect such cases? Lets test

In machine learning , ‘Garbage In is Garbage Out’ so make sure that you perform required data operations before using your data for training the model — here we converted entire data to lowercase, removed XML, HTML tags like
  • , etc., special symbols and stop-words relevant for the use case.
A Product Image having lots of text.
Text Extracted using OCR👉 B-Complex Mutimineras,With Antioxidants Capsules Minreal Promotes Energy Metabolism Supports Heart Health Ria

Some products have images with text written on them. Extracting that text and feeding that into the model also helped us to better categorize the product as ‘Banned’ or ‘Approved’. OCR(Optical Character Recognition) was used here to extract the relevant data from the image.
OCR stands for Optical Character Recognition. Using OCR we can scan images and documents containing texts and converts them into documents that can be edited.
In our case, OCR helps us to extract text from product images, more importantly in cases where no textual information is available in the Product Name, Product Description, and Specification.
Google Cloud Vision API and Tesseract can be explored for this.

As of now, the model is accurate for every 85/100 products being tested by it when we match results with a human auditor. Another fact that I am able to gather is that ‘the real world is not as easily classified as we tend to believe’, the use of a human will always be necessary to determine “gray areas” that require a human touch. I am working on reducing these gray areas and will soon come up with a follow-up article. Please refer to Part II of this series for further read.
